lines.text: Would you like to buy a Christmas wreath?
It's not even Thanksgiving yet. By the time Christmas comes, all the needles will be falling off.
Don't hang it near the turkey.
[the correct line is "Hark"]
Hockey stick!
Would you like to buy a Christmas wreath?
It isn't even Thanksgiving yet.
Would you like to buy a Thanksgiving wreath?
Behold, I am the handmaiden of the Lord.

[while Marcie is speaking]
Baa! Baa! Baa! Baa!
I am Gabriel, Mary, and I couldn't hear you because of the sheep.
And there were shepherds in the field watching their flocks by night.
Woof! Meow! Moo! Whatever.
[everyone in the audience laughs]
And a partridge in a pear tree.

[on the phone, to Marcie]
Marcie, what book were we supposed to read during Thanksgiving vacation?
This is Christmas vacation, sir.
Christmas vacation? How can I read something during Christmas vacation, when I didn't read what I was supposed to read during Thanksgiving vacation?
Duck, sir. Easter is coming.

[Marcie and Peppermint Patty are walking to their school Christmas play]
Watch out for the curb here, sir.
What?
[she trips on the curb, in her sheep costume]
Slouching towards Bethlehem, huh, sir?
I can't stand it!
Good morning, would you like to buy a Christmas wreath made from some junky old branches my brother found in a Christmas tree lot? You wouldn't would you? And I can't say I blame you.

[on the phone]
Sally thinks someone named Harold Angel is going to sing for her.

[doorbell rings]
Excuse me, somebody's at the door.
[Charlie Brown opens the door]
Hi, is Sally home? My name is Herold Angel.

[looking at a cardboard box on top of a pine tree]
I think they look better when they have a little star or an angel on top.
Guess what, Chuck. Disaster time. Our teacher wants us to read a book during Christmas vacation. Got any suggestions?
On what book to read?
No! On how to get out of it!
Why aren't you reading your book, sir?

It's too nice a day to stay inside and read, Marcie. Besides, I have to build this snowman. If I don't do it, no one else will, and he won't exist. I am his creator, and it is my duty to give him life! This snowman has a right to live, Marcie!
You're weird, sir.
How do you spell your name?
I'm your brother, and you don't even know how to spell my name?
I'll put down "Sam". I know how to spell that.

I said "hockey stick"! Why did I say "hockey stick"? All I had to say was "hark", and I said "hockey stick"! I ruined the whole Christmas play! Everybody hates me! Moses hates me, Luke hates me, the Apostles hate me! All fifty of them!
Okay, get up! I want to lie in that beanbag!
Remember when we were siting around the Christmas tree opening our presents? That's when you said it.
That's when I said what?
It was beautiful. You said, "Why do we have to be nice to each other only on Christmas? Why can't we be nice to each other every day?"
You drive me crazy!
Joy to the world.

I'm not going to have to read a book, Marcie. See? "A Tale of Two Cities" was just on TV. I watched the movie, so now I won't have to read the book. The only thing I didn't understand were the parts about the shampoo, the soap, and the coffee.
Those were the commercials, sir.
I want to buy Peggy Jean a nice pair of gloves for Christmas, but they cost $25.
She's going to be dissappointed when she finds out that her boyfriend is a cheapskate.
I'm not a cheapskate, I just don't have $25.
Put it on your credit card.
I don't have a credit card.
So long, Peggy Jean.
Where are you going to get $25?
That's the problem.
Maybe you can sell your dog.
[Snoopy blows a raspberry]
I take it back. He's probably only worth 50 cents.
I'm going to ask the teacher if I could be Mary in the Christmas play this year.
She's already asked me, sir.
I think I'll be great in the part.
She asked me yesterday.
I like the part where the angel of Gabriel talks to me.
Why would the angel of Gabriel talk to you? He'd never listen.
I could probably wear these same sandles.
[raises her hand]
[Teacher mumbles]
Yes, ma'am, I'd like to volunteer to play the part of Mary in our Chrismtas play.
[Teacher mumbles]
YOU WHAT?

[Teacher mumbles]
That's right, sir. She asked me yesterday.
Mary never wore glasses!
Hey, Chuck, did Mary ever wear glasses?
[pause]
What do you mean "Mary Who"? In the Bible! Does it say anything about Mary wearing glasses?
[pause]
Then how come Marcie played Mary instead of me? And the teacher says I have to play a sheep!
Why can't I ever be a wrong number?
I live in mortal dread of getting out on stage and forgetting what I am to say.
Well, if you did, you could always make up something.
That's true. How about "Hey"?
Not very Biblical.
This is the line I have to say in the Christmas play. See if I get it right.
[hands Charlie Brown the script]
Hark!
You got it. I've always wondered how actors remember all those lines.
I was up late last night memorizing all of my lines.
All your lines?... I can't remember my lines, Marcie!
You're a sheep, sir. All you have to say is "Baa".
My mind is going blank! I'm doomed! I wonder if this ever happened to Laurence Olivier?
I can't remember my lines, Marcie!
All you have to say is "Baa".
My mind is going blank! I'll never remember! Why do they have to spoil Christmas by making us be in plays?
We're on, Sir. Let's show them how!
[Snoopy is dressed as Santa Claus; ringing a bell while standing outside a store]
[as she and Violet walk past him]
Wouldn't you think he could do something besides ring a bell?
[Snoopy stops ringing the bell and pulls out a bike horn]
[Lucy walks past Snoopy again; this time with Linus]

[to Linus]
Just ignore that Santa Claus, Linus. There's nothing he can do to you.
[Snoopy honks the horn so hard, it sends Linus and Lucy flying offscreen]

[Lucy walks back and confronts Snoopy]
I don't think you're a real Santa Claus. What do you have to say about that?
[Snoopy responds by putting the horn to Lucy's nose and honking it in her face; sending her winter hat flying off her head]
[Lucy leaves and Sally enters]

[confronting Snoopy]
I don't think you're the real Santa Claus. If you're the real Santa, where are your helpers?
[Woodstock and two of his friends, who are all wearing Santa hats walk past each holding picket signs with the word, "HELP" written on them, much to Sally's surprise]
That's the dumbest thing I'd ever seen.
Why can't I ever be a wrong number?
[first lines]
[Sally and Linus are preparing to sled down a hill in a cardboard box]

[to Linus]
Now what? Kinda a steep hill, isn't it?
Don't worry about it. Just lean forward and jiggle your feet.

[Sally climbs out of the box]
I think I've changed my mind.
[the box falls an inch off the slope; Linus is then face planted in the snow]
If I'd have known you were only going that far, I would've stayed in.
[Linus tries again]
Here we go. We put it in fast forward, and here we go!

[Linus slides backwards down the slope; the box lands on top of him]
Fast reverse.
[Linus' third attempt involves him sliding down the hill at a fast speed; the box then lands on top of a tree]
[camera pulls back to reveal that Linus landed in the snow as Sally and Lucy are standing there]

[to Sally]
I think they look better when they have a little star or an angel on top.
[Sally and Charlie Brown are selling Christmas wreaths door-to-door]

[to customer]
Good morning, ask your mom if she would like to buy a Christmas wreath. Tell her they were made from the famous forests of Lebanon. You can read about him in the second chapter of the second book of "Chronicles". If you buy two, we'll throw in an autographed photo of King Solomon.

[to Sally; as they walk to the next house]
You can't tell people these wreaths were made from the forests of Lebanon! That's lying!
[the two arrive at the next house as Sally rings the doorbell]

[rudely]
Good morning. Would you like to buy a Christmas wreath made from some junky old branches my brother found in a Christmas tree lot? You wouldn't, would you? I can't say I blame you.

[to Charlie Brown; after the customers slams the door]
See? Your way doesn't work either!
[fade to Sally and Snoopy contemplating how to sell the wreaths]
we need a better way to show off our product.
[cut to Sally and Snoopy selling wreaths door-to-door; Snoopy is wearing the wreath on his nose]

[to the customer]
Good morning, would you like to buy a Christmas wreath?
Good morning, this is a Christmas wreath.

[snatches wreath away from Charlie Brown]
Thank you, I love samples.
[as Charlie Brown is selling Christmas wreaths door-to-door]

[to an adult]
Good morning, sir. Would you like to buy a nice Christmas wreath?
[the homeowner slams the door in Charlie Brown's face sending both him and the wreath flying backwards into the snow]

[after spitting out snow]
Merry Christmas anyway, sir. "God bless us, everyone," said Tiny Tim, the last of all, "and joy to the world!"

[picks up the wreath and heads home]
Rats!
I'd like to read this book, Marcie. But I'm kinda afraid. I had a grandfather who didn't think much of reading. He always said, "If you read too many books, your head would fall off!"
You start the first chapter, Sir. I'll hold onto your head.
What was Handel's first name, Marcie?
I'm ashamed to admit, I don't know.
I'll just have to guess.
